awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Harold Blum is "Singularities and K-stability". The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Utah, and the sponsoring scientist is Tommaso de Fernex.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The PI was funded by NSF grant 1803102 during the tenure of his postdoctoral research at the University of Utah and Stony Brook University. The grant allowed the PI to conduct research in algebraic geometry, attend conferences, and visit collaborators. These activities resulted in the PI writing seven papers. In addition, the PI took part in broader impact activities including speaking in a graduate student summer workshop and organizing seminars aimed at graduate students. 

The research component of the project focused on algebraic geometry, which is an area of mathematics that studies shapes defined by polynomial equations. These shapes are called algebraic varieties and appear not just in pure mathematics, but in fields from computer science to theoretical physics.

The project focused on a recent notion in algebraic geometry called K-stability. This is a definition introduced by differential geometers to characterize when complex algebraic varieties admit certain canonical metrics. While the definition originally seemed quite foreign to algebraists, there has been significant progress in understanding K-stability algebraically. This notion is particularly interesting when studying Fano varieties, which are one of the three building blocks of varieties in algebraic geometry.

An important reason for studying K-stability is in its applications to moduli theory, which aims to construct parameter spaces for certain classes of algebraic varieties. While it has long been known that Fano varieties do not have a well behaved moduli theory, recent research has shown that K-stable Fano varieties do indeed admit a good moduli theory. 

In this project, the PI used recent advances in K-stability to study properties of K-stable Fano varieties. For example, the PI and collaborators showed that K-stability is an open condition in families, K-polystable Fano varieties have reductive automorphism group, and that the moduli spaces of K-polystable Fano varieties exists and is Hausdorff. These advances were vital steps in the recent construction of compact moduli spaces of K-stable Fano varieties.

Modified by: Harold Blum
